Mike Stone

@mike

Husband, father, nerd. Half human, half Fosstodon Admin. Tends to tell Dad Jokes.

Don't feel obligated, but if you feel like buying me a coffee, I won't say no...

:cupofcoffee: https://ko-fi.com/mikestone :cupofcoffee:

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-08 17:52

@grueproof Right? About the only thing I've found that I miss is a full screen view. I like hitting F11 and just having the terminal take the whole screen. No menu bars. No icons. Just my terminal. In Ghostty's defense though, Ptyxis didn't do that either and that's been my daily driver for a while now. I'm not losing that feature by moving to Ghostty.

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-08 17:27

@mykhaylo Before that I was using Ptyxis.

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-08 17:21

I finally took the plunge and installed #Ghostty. I've been seeing it in the news all over the place and had to see if it lived up to the hype. So far it's been stable and fast for me. I'm going to daily drive it for a while and see if it holds up, but so far I'm impressed.

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-04 22:30

@dev_ric Immortality and mortality have the exact same shortcoming, and that's a lack of control.

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-04 18:10

@dev_ric Yea, everybody loved hyping up the "overdue for eruption" bit, but they'd bury in their articles that they were talking geologic time scales, and their "any day" was probably in the thousands of years range. Now it turns out that even those estimates were wildly off. Don't get me wrong, Yellowstone is still a super volcano. One of the largest in the world. When it does erupt it's going to be catastrophic. But barring major innovation in immortality research, we're not going to see it.

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-03 23:20

@tim It's a very fine line, and crossing to the wrong side of it can actually hurt your cause. Unfortunately (and especially on social media) what can be meant to be helpful can come across as "reply guy" and dismissed out of hand. Extreme care needs to be taken, and often it's not.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-03 23:10

So, it appears we're safe for the next couple hundred of thousand of years. Probably.

I remember talking to people on IRC back when I was living in #Bozeman, MT who were surprised I wasn't more afraid to live only 100 miles away from one of the largest volcanoes in the world. Looks like I was OK to not be all that worried.

https://arstechnica.com/science/2025/01/study-melt-underneath-yellowstone-shows-it-isnt-poised-to-erupt-soon

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-02 16:25

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-02 16:25

@GreyLinux I do use Netlify and GitHub for the site. The domain costs me about $17 per year. Hosting with Netlify is free with the plan I'm using, so $17 total. I just update the GitHub repo and Netlify processes everything. Honestly, I don't even have Jekyll installed anymore. Once you get the site created and uploaded to GitHub all the Jekyll stuff happens on Netlify's end of the process. It would probably be better if I did for testing and all that, but I just test in prod. ðŸ˜‰

Mike Stone @mike 2025-01-02 15:44

@GreyLinux Hey! I'd love to claim that I'm an expert at any of this, but I'm as lazy about my blog as I am about most things. I used to use write.as for my blog, but they were having issues with some stuff, so and Kev published this article around the same time.

https://kevquirk.com/blog/how-to-build-jekyll-site-simple-css

I really just followed his instructions and migrated my stuff off write.as. I made some really minor adjustments to make it a little bit more "mine", but it's pretty close to just following those directions.

@BasicAppleGuy

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-31 21:06

@BasicAppleGuy I started a new job not long after Y2K. A friend of mine was already working there. New Years Eve, 1999 the whole IT team was required to work, "just in case". They were all gathered right outside the server room watching the ball drop. Midnight approached, and they started their countdown. 5... 4... 3... 2... 1... and at the stroke of midnight, my friend turned off the overhead lights. There were people that were still angry with him for it when I joined the team months later.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-30 18:48

@evacide This feels like an obvious play to get people to spend more time on their system so they can gather more information on their users and potentially manipulate choices those people make. I wonder where the threshold is for this information actually being useful to them is. When does it stop? I mean, if they know what I had for breakfast, that might be useful sorta? But does it really matter if I had breakfast at 9:17AM vs 9:22AM? When is the cutoff on investment return?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-29 21:56

@justincroser I can't say for sure to be honest. All feedback regarding reports is handled via email, and we don't get a copy of it. I can see there were some reports some months back, but nothing I would call super serious. The posts the warnings were for were removed, so I don't know what caused the reports.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-29 08:36

@justincroser Usually. It's possible to appeal a warning, and if the moderation team accepts the appeal (which does happen sometimes), that warning will be removed from your account. Otherwise, they're pretty much there forever. Please keep in mind that warnings can happen for a variety of reasons, and not all warnings hold the same weight. They all look the same, but we actually read those when we see them.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-28 23:50

@jawsh Happy to help!

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-28 22:11

@justincroser Let me know if there's anything you need!

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-24 19:31

@JayT Yep, if you support them or their show, you're indirectly contributing to pushing crypto. Your contribution helps them make their show in a variety of ways, and if they use their show(s) to push crypto, you've contributed to that. I'm not a listener myself, so I can't speak for the content of the shows, but I can assume that crypto isn't the only thing they talk about. The bigger question, and harder, is whether their non-crypto content is worth it to you.

@molly0xfff @geerlingguy @kev

It's my personal feeling that at best, it's too volatile to be a viable currency, even without considering all its other aspects. I feel a little silly even commenting on this when someone like @molly0xfff is on the thread. She's far more knowledgeable about the subject than I am.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-22 02:36

@vkc I don't understand what the vitriol is about. When I started using Linux, you pretty much had to compile all of your apps with Make. Then I tried some RPMs, and then moved to apt. Then I tried some Snaps and AppImages and Flatpaks. I find that at the end of the day, when I sit down at my computer after being at work all day and I'm tired and I click on the icon to load an application, I just don't care about any of that. Sometimes I just want to read the news or chat with friends.

I use #Vivaldi as my browser, and it's just slick on any platform. I can legitimately say it's easier for me to use than #Windows11. Less stupid too.

@thibaultmol @ianthetechie Honestly, the whole iMessage thing is one of the issues between iOS and Android that actually makes me angry. I don't want this to be all about @kev's personal situation, but he points out in his post the Google apps missing from his Mac. Where are the Apple apps on Windows? Android? Linux? Anywhere not Apple?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-17 16:18

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-17 16:13

Then I sign into Fosstodon and, "What? You've created your own processor out of bailing twine and a stick of bubble gum? That's so interesting! I'm going to wait over here while you create nuclear fusion with an old microwave, some rusty nails, and an orange."

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-16 22:44

@kev Yep, Apple has blocked that interoperability specifically to make it hard for people like yourself. Their stuff only truly works if you buy in wholesale.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-16 21:35

@CyborgZeta Apple's control of their entire stack means they're the only one that can do specific things with offerings. It's not that other's can't, and if Apple was more open with their ecosystem others very well may do it better. Apple prevents others from competing. If Apple managed to pull a bigger chunk of the market, it would ABSOLUTELY be considered anti-competitive behavior. The only reason they're able to do it is because they don't have majority control over the market.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-16 18:32

@dusnm Well, I want a phone that doesn't choke when I have 100 tabs open in my browser. I want to have one of the best screens and best cameras you can find, and I want it to be my choice how I use those things. Unlike @kev, I don't mind having a big phone. I'm getting older, so the larger screen means larger text for me to read, and that's better.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-16 18:28

@kev Well, I make an effort not to be heavily invested in any specific ecosystem. I use an Android phone, but I don't use Gmail for my primary mail. I don't use Google Calendar. I don't use Chrome. I don't use Google Photos. I use apps from the Play store, and moving to any other ecosystem would suck if I lost those, but they're not a deal breaker. I don't like being locked in. Anywhere. Google's bad enough, but Apple is infinitely worse when it comes to lock in.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-16 16:52

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-08 03:16

@homeassistant The biggest difference I see? That Pi 5 is faster by far than that VM I had before. Lots. The Pi 5 is arguably overkill, but as easy as these things are to restore, I'd rather have this be the last time I have to do this for a good long while. The Pi 5 isn't "future proof", but it's definitely "future resistant".

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-08 03:14

Sadly, my @homeassistant server fell down and went boom. It wasn't the fault of Home Assistant in any way. I was running HA on an old box as a virtual machine, and the host ate it. All the other VMs were test machines, so no big, but the HA was a big deal. So, I bought a Pi 5, installed Home Assistant from the Raspberry Pi Imager, and plugged it in. It says, Welcome! Do you want to set this up or restore a backup. Restore of course! In less than 30 minutes, it's back like it never left. Love it!

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-06 22:03

@fedops Oh yea, we've got one of those too, but it's web based so we don't have an icon on our system for it. Wow that would be annoying as hell if there was.

I don't need to bury them in my home directory Documents or Downloads. As soon as I'm done I want them gone. That's why stuff I can't get rid of is so annoying on my desktop in particular. My Start Menu is still littered in useless junk, but at least that's behind the button. The desktop is constantly in my face.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-12-05 20:53

@mookie My off the cuff thoughts on the matter done with absolutely no research at all, so grain of salt here, is that the Fediverse should be a better source for real-time news with the smaller population being the only consideration. Here, you don't have to worry about whether your tsunami warning isn't going to get through because some algorithm decided it wasn't content you were going to want to see, or maybe you would prefer to see it tomorrow. No algorithm, just a chronological timeline.

Mike Stone boosted
Jon S. von Tetzchner @jon 2024-11-26 19:48

When I talk about the importance of going all in on the Fediverse, I speak based on experience.

At Opera we built a massive user community. When I quit, we had something like 35 million registered users and 35 million monthly visitors.

The new Opera management did not see the value of that. They believed it was cheaper and better to just use Facebook and that investing in your own community was a waste of money. So they closed down MyOpera and built a following on Facebook and Twitter instead. Then they got caught by the bait and switch when Facebook changed and you would no longer reach your audience, without paying. Later on Twitter changed as well.

This is important to explain to companies and institutions as they go shopping for social media sites to invest in. The best investment is clearly in your own site, being part of the Fediverse. It is not even all that expensive to do. It may take longer to build, but at least it is your own.

Not saying you cannot build a following on those other sites, but your long term strategy should be the Fediverse with your own server.

We try to lead the way here and thus we build Vivaldi Social. Not just for our selves, but to make a point and support the Fediverse.

#fediverse #Mastodon #Twitter #Threads #BlueSky #Vivaldi

@Strwpok Absolutely true. I was just going off the article's "aimed at challenging Google Chrome" bit. I don't think that's going to happen. Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-23 22:39

I'm not sure OpenAI knows what they're getting into with this venture. If Alphabet/Google is forced to sell Chrome off, they might have a chance, but as the market currently exists they have almost no chance of being able to kick Chrome out of the top spot on the leaderboard. Are they planning their own engine? Good luck with that. Are they going to be a Chromium based browser with ChatGPT integration? Won't compete with Google. A Firefox fork? I can't see it winning.

https://www.computerworld.com/article/3611399/openai-is-thinking-about-building-its-own-browser.html

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-22 21:18

@tripplehelix Yea, I saw a lot of discussion about adding the tags to pages, but almost nobody mentioned the Verification changes. Also, just a heads up, it's not retroactive. Your old posts still won't have the link.

@foo @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-22 21:14

@tripplehelix That's not a feature that we as admins/moderators can turn on or off. When I set mine up, the thing that I didn't initially realize was you have to go into Preferences -> Public Profile -> Verification and add the domains you want to enable before the tags will mean anything. Did everybody do that already? I don't see it in the thread.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-20 19:12

@jgamble There's a subset of the greater Fediverse that has elected to block Fosstodon as a whole. Fosstodon does the same thing with other instances when our moderation staff feels it's warranted. Last time I checked, the number of instances blocking Fosstodon accounted for less than 1% of the population of the Fed. More instances block @SallyStrange's instance than block Fosstodon. Still, if you have any questions or concerns about it, don't hesitate to ask.

@hlesesne I think your posts have had some interesting information, but you may also want to consider changing the permissions to something not just public. Public posts show up in everybody's Local timeline, and you get reported for automated spam. A lot. I know you're monitoring the account and it's all good, but you might want to consider going Unlisted or Followers Only.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-13 21:19

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-13 20:14

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-13 17:06

@ikt Heh, full time from home, and my wife already complains about where the AC/heat is set.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-13 16:31

One feature I'd love to see #Vivaldi add would be rendering RSS feeds in panels. Sometimes I want to follow an RSS feed, but only temporarily and it would be really nice to just have it in a panel. @Vivaldi has added this cool feature where RSS feeds get rendered in a simple web UI, but if you add that same RSS feed to a panel, it doesn't do it. There's a handy button to switch between desktop and mobile views for panels, but it does nothing for RSS feeds. I just want the right, on the left.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-13 16:03

Ahh, we've settled nicely into "Coffee Weather".

I love coffee. Black, no sugar. My biggest problem is I just don't like hot drinks when it's hot. And I live in Arizona. It gets hot here (Yes, it's a dry heat. I know). So, when summer rolls around, I just don't want to drink coffee, and I miss it. It's nice to get into cooler weather where I can have my coffee and not be sweating the whole time.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-12 21:15

@daniel The website permissions section lets you adjust stuff about each site individually. There's a section in there where you can block Javascript on a site by site basis, but unfortunately there's not a way to click and toggle on the fly, which would be nice. It also lets you provide exceptions for cookies, so if you do something like have session only cookies enabled, you can create exceptions to that rule in that section. I feel like I'm missing stuff.

2/2

@tylersticka @Vivaldi @floorp

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-12 21:13

@daniel Well, clicking on the shield in the address bar gives the generic options. If you choose "Manage Default Settings" it'll bring you to your blocker settings. In there, there's the Exceptions, which lets you add/subtract exceptions to defaults. There's a "Manage Sources" button there that allows you to add/subtract Ad blocker and Tracking blocker lists. You can give it a URL or open a local file. Down below is Website Permissions.

1/2

@tylersticka @Vivaldi @floorp

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-12 19:25

@daniel For the record, Vivaldi allows you to edit and create custom rules for specific domains as well. For CSS, I use Stylus and Quick Javascript Switcher for the other bits.

@tylersticka @Vivaldi @floorp

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-12 14:21

@daniel For what it's worth, Vivaldi has great integrated adblocking that isn't impacted by Google's manifest changes. I don't even use a 3rd party blocker and I've had better luck with Vivaldi than I did with Zen/AdBlockPro. It even allows you to import additional ad lists, so I've brought in the lists from this link without any issues.

https://github.com/uBlockOrigin/uAssets/tree/master/filters

This works great for me, but if the goal is to actually use the plugin, it doesn't help you.

@tylersticka @Vivaldi @floorp

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-11 22:49

@tylersticka "I do question if Iâ€™m the right fit for a product I ignore 95% of."

I wouldn't worry much. Vivaldi is designed to be feature rich, but you're not going to use it all. Heck, some of it just offers different ways to do the same thing, so you can adjust how you use Vivaldi to your personal workflow. Those features you don't use now might be something you pick up later, or just never pick up. If you need/want it, it's there. If not, you're under no obligation from anybody.

@Vivaldi

@jackwilliambell Yea, you're (like us) invite only. These guys aren't hacking Mastodon or anything like that, they're just creating a lot of accounts on instances no one watches. Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-04 21:57

@writer13 I'm honestly torn. I often find myself having to trim my post to bring it down under the 500 character limit, wishing I had just a dozen more characters to play with. Unfortunately increasing the character limit in Mastodon is kinda annoying and not permanent between updates, so we've elected not to do it.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-04 21:50

There's another spam wave going on right now. Hopefully most of you haven't noticed because we've been catching it before it gets to our community. Unfortunately, much of this spam is coming from instances with small moderation staff or unmonitored instances. In those situations, we're having to block those instances completely. If you find you're trying to follow an account on a blocked instance, let us know so we can unblock for you.

You can see who we block here:

https://fosstodon.org/about

Mike Stone @mike 2024-11-04 21:35

@hund Hopefully! I can say that I haven't experienced anything I would remotely classify as a "high", but my old method made me ache, especially in my ankles and shins. I'd be sore all day, and I think it was impacting my mood negatively just in general. This new method, I don't feel that way. I get done with my run, I grab something to drink, and the rest of my day isn't dramatically different than a day I don't run. I feel pretty normal. I'm going to start breaking out the free weights.

It's only been a couple days and I've already seen the distance I can go without elevating my heart rate almost double! It's been less than a week, and I know that's not sustainable, but still....

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-31 18:00

Hey @brandon,

We don't require people go out and reply to other people's posts to be considered "active". The metric we're mostly looking for is if the account is monitored. We send them a message and if they notice and reply, we usually consider that good. If nobody is replying to their posts, we don't expect them to force interaction some other way.

We appreciate the reports you've been filing lately. They've all been followed-up on with the reported parties.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-26 00:29

The weekend is finally here. :eyebags:

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-25 16:31

@rapidscampi Vivaldi has had built in ad/tracker blocking for a couple years now. I don't think it's going to help out with YouTube content since I don't think it'll block in-video advertising. It's absolutely not impacted by Manifest v3 because Manifest v3 basically defines how extensions work with the browser. Vivaldi's adblocking isn't done with an extension, so the version of Manifest just never comes into the picture. As I said though, I don't think it's going to help in-video stuff.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-24 18:11

@rapidscampi I was concerned about it when I first heard, but I did some comparisons with my personal web activity and I'm less worried now. I compared Firefox with uBlock Origin to Vivaldi just using its integrated ad/tracker blocking, and for how I use the web, Vivaldi was still better at blocking ads and trackers. Vivaldi's integrated ad/tracker blocking won't be impacted by the move to Manifest v3, so Vivaldi will still have exceptional ad blocking capability even after the roll out.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-17 17:03

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-16 18:18

Political campaigns these days have too much money. They throw it around without a thought.

Today we received two political flyers that were exactly the same. Name, address, etc. They literally sent out two because they were too lazy to do this:

SELECT v.first_name, v.last_name, v.street_address, v.city, v.state, v.zip_code
FROM voters v
JOIN mailer m ON v.voter_id = m.voter_id
WHERE m.send_date > DATE_ADD(NOW(), INTERVAL -14 DAY)
GROUP BY v.voter_id;

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-14 03:55

@4c31 Yea, it was definitely a decision not everybody agreed with, but Kev and I only started Fosstodon with the idea of a place for us to be. We thought we'd get a dozen people to join us. Two if we were being super optimistic. 11,000+ active users is well beyond what we anticipated. If Fosstodon wasn't federated, we'd probably not made the same choice. Since it is and we can still communicate with the greater Fediverse, it made sense for us. Plus, we're still pulling in ~1000 new users a year.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-11 22:48

@ilookloud Not to mention no one seems to be asking what I think are important questions. For example, why do the statistics show a loss of 500k users on the 18th of January? I don't think the person who created this graph is intentionally trying to mislead people. Odds are good they're just working with the information they have. I do think judging the prospects of Mastodon as a whole by a single line a chart isn't wise.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-04 18:57

@cooper Hmm, @kev is probably a better choice to answer this question. I haven't put any real research into it. Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-04 04:42

@badrihippo After that, removed the obnoxious stuff and reselected just the logo area. I created a new layer and filled that outline with white to fill in any remaining transparencies lingering around (gradients can be a real pain) and then merged the layers. Then I used the border tool under the select menu to add a 5px border around the outside. After that, it was just a crop to content, expand the vertical and center, and resize to 500x500 and exporting as PNG.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-04 04:39

@badrihippo I took the original image, which already had a transparent background. I increased the canvas size to give me some room to work. I selected all based on color and picked a transparent section of the image. Then I manually added in the stripes and the internal transparent stuff. That gave me the outline. I inverted the selection and filled with something obnoxious so I could easily remove it again later. Then I filled in the remaining transparent stuff with the bucket.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2024-10-04 03:04

@badrihippo I don't do much image editing, so the only thing I have is GIMP.

@fosstodon

@sister_ratched I'd also suggest looking through your past posts to a point when you know you were talking with Vicky. Your past mentions would still be there, but the link to Vicky's profile would just be a @profile@instancename.com kinda thing.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-13 19:25

@LateNightLinux It's worth noting a lot of the motivation behind Valve's Linux initiatives was self preservation. They needed a means of gaming outside of the Microsoft Windows ecosystem due to Microsoft's EEE tendencies. Valve didn't want to be on the receiving end of that EEE, so developing in the Linux space was a CYA move. It COULD be argued that Microsoft is one of the largest proprietary companies driving desktop Linux innovation. If you don't like Steam doing it, you'll hate that.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-13 15:52

@Coffmans Wowza. I consider myself a pretty tab heavy person, but I'm an amateur compared to Hazel. I've only got 124 tabs open right now.

https://fosstodon.org/invite/JCUZMiXt

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-12 21:38

@ElenLeFoll It's fairly trivial to mirror your Mastodon activity to Twitter using services like IFTTT (free version), but that wouldn't reflect likes or replies back to Mastodon. It's pretty much a one way street. Of course, it could serve as an incentive to people who are following you to migrate to the Fediverse themselves. Personally, I'd see that as the best case scenario, but I can only speak for myself.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-06 18:28

@pybay Well, assuming you're using the web UI for your manually tagging, all you need to do is click on the globe at the bottom of your post and change the permission level to your desired audience. If you're using an app on your phone like Tusky or the official Mastodon app, it'll be a little different, but similar.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-06 18:23

@pybay How are you posting these tag posts? Are you using the web UI or an app?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-06 18:19

@pybay Just a heads up. When you do this, you're posting an empty message to literally everybody on Fosstodon's local timeline. It's been noticed and there have been some reports for spamming. I realize you're not spamming and I understand what your intent here is, but I wanted to let you know. It might work better to change the post permissions to Unlisted or even Mentioned People Only. It would probably still have the desired result and it wouldn't show up in the local timelines of everybody.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-05 15:27

@lulu_powerful My thoughts as well. When I heard they were making a Minecraft movie, I couldn't for the life of me think of what that would look like. Still, it wasn't THAT.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-05 02:49

@dev_ric Unfortunately it's a risk required for my sanity.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-04 19:50

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-04 16:44

I always score poorly on our corporate phishing detection tests. They send out these fake phishing emails to see if you'll report them, and I never do. I get so much email that I just ignore most of it. If the from address is not someone I know personally and I'm expecting email from, I don't even bother looking at it, and that includes their fake phishes. Because of this, I end up "needing" training yearly to get "better" at phishing detection. I refuse to open emails just to find fake phish.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-03 21:56

@FunctionKey Well, that's not the real IP range. I just converted our actual IP space to 192.168 for that post. I haven't worked anywhere that used that space on a corporate level. I have worked in a company that used 10.10, but never 192.168. I can't even imagine the trouble THAT would cause.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-03 19:17

Sometimes being a nerd that works with a lot of non-nerds sucks a whole lot. I just had to explain that "192.168.0.0 through 192.168.0.16" is VERY different from "192.168.0.0/16". Easy mistake to make, huge ramifications.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-03 17:35

#Pine64

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-03 15:39

@rl_dane I'm not aware of any ongoing issues. Our queues are clear and the instance seems to be responding as we would expect it to. What issues are still outstanding?

@amoroso @lulu_powerful @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-03 15:38

@amoroso It took longer for larger instances to recover than the smaller ones. After the issues with object storage were resolved, there was a veritable flood of messages we hadn't been receiving, which overloaded the servers for several hours. Smaller instances with fewer users didn't have the massive queue to catch up on, so they recovered more quickly.

@lulu_powerful @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-02 21:49

@tripplehelix @borisv It's something we've talked about in the past, but at present the method for increasing the character limit is editing backend configuration files, which have to be redone after each update. As such, we've elected to stay with the default 500 for now. If the character limit moves into the DB where it's a configurable option in the admin control panel, we'll revisit the character limit at that time. Sorry.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-09-02 04:02

@tripplehelix @gairsty We didn't hide it per se. It's not visible unless you're authenticated to the instance. We wanted to be transparent with our community, but we didn't want to provide a map to the worst parts of the Fediverse to anybody wanting to look. We thought this was a good middle ground.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-30 21:32

@FinchHaven I think the fact that they're being prevented from using Twitter against their will is potentially a big factor. It would be for me. It points out the vulnerability of centralized services, and if it were me I'd be looking for something a little bit more resilient. I can't speak to whether these are people we WANT, I'm just curious if they're coming.

@joel @vmstan

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-30 21:24

@joel I'm not really trying to look at this from a political angle. I'm just considering the practical implications of a service that people use going away suddenly. Are those people going to be looking for alternatives (Mastodon, Threads, Bluesky, whatever) or do we think they're just going to wait it out or sign off permanently?

@FinchHaven @vmstan

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-30 20:49

@zachklipp I'm not sure. There's a big difference between choosing to move to Mastodon when you have Twitter, and looking for alternatives because Twitter just vanished. I also think this kind of move by the judge could drive home how vulnerable non-distributed services are. One judge publishes one decision, and your stuff goes away. As long as you're using a service like Twitter, you're going to be vulnerable. A lot of people could be feeling pretty vulnerable right about now.

@vmstan

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-30 20:32

I'm not a huge fan of Twitter these days, and apparently neither is this judge. Do we think a Twitter ban in Brazil could result in a wave of new Mastodon users or is this just going to blow over with no change?

https://www.reuters.com/technology/lula-says-musk-must-respect-brazils-top-court-x-braces-shutdown-2024-08-30/

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-28 18:00

Hey @jonburdo, fancy seeing you here. ðŸ˜‰

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-28 17:48

When you're creating an invitation to #Fosstodon, please remember to give that invitation an expiration time. If you don't, those invites can be scraped by search engines and YOUR invite can be used by anybody. If you don't know if you've left any invites with no expiration, you can go to your Preferences->Invite People to see the list of invites you've created. Any with an infinity sign in the Expires column should be Deactivated.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-25 20:01

@yabozdar Ah. I dropped a note to my little brother, who actually is an English teacher, and he said "came out" is correct. The trick is in when things happen. So, if you're waiting to learn results of something that's over, "came out". If you're waiting to learn results of something that hasn't happened yet, "comes out". He did note that my particular grammatical choices there were pretty uncommon in general use. I guess I'm just weird. Sorry about that. ðŸ˜‰

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-25 19:16

@yabozdar Well, "all comes out" would be correct if you were talking the final grade because that has yet to be determined and will depend on the results of this project. I was thinking more about the final project itself, which is done. It's finished. So, it's past tense. Nothing I can do at this point is going to change it, hence the "came out". I'm honestly not sure if that's grammatically correct according to the rules, I just know that's how it works in my head.

Thoth - a widget engine @thothwidgets 2024-08-22 16:04

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-22 17:36

@LateNightLinux Whether we SHOULD try to convert them is a little bit more nuanced. People like their tools, and they like what's comfortable to them. I think it's a bad idea to put pressure on people to switch. You push and they're going to push back. The best way to get someone to switch is just give them a taste of FOMO. If they see your computer running smoothly, easily, and without ads or crazy AI tools mucking up your workflow, that could be all it takes to get them to consider switching.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-22 16:08

@LateNightLinux For work, I'm pretty much stuck with Windows, but I use WSL HEAVILY. If you're using WSL, you're not in the "normie" category of user. We just need to point out Linux has gotten so easy to use since I started with it back in the 90s there's very little a WSL user can't do with a standard desktop Linux install. Cloud apps like Office 365 and native apps mean virtually all bases are covered, except annoying ads built in and crazy LLMs telling us lies masquerading as facts.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-22 15:52

@kev Suck it up young whippersnapper. On my 40th I went ziplining in Vegas with my pregnant wife!

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 21:24

@graves501 Posts donâ€™t need to be long-form, deep, meaningful, or even that well written. Just write about what you want to write about. @kev put up a page that details all the rules.

@tatertot @joel Not really. What do you have for your settings for your notifications?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 21:03

@adamsdesk By the way, I'm a huge nerd about this. I'll talk your ears off about Vivaldi if you're not careful. ðŸ˜

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 21:02

@adamsdesk Well, the only ones in memory at any given time are the ones that aren't hibernated. For me, everything that hasn't been accessed in the last hour is hibernated. Workspaces are super handy though. There's a workspace that's dedicated to the window you're in, but all the rest can be accessed from any window. You can literally open a new window and just switch to an existing workspace and all the tabs from that workspace are in the new window. No lifting and shifting. Super handy.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:51

@adamsdesk I also use tab stacks quite a bit. If I open a new tab from an existing one, those tabs stack automatically so they're grouped and they stay together. I can create two rows of tabs, one for the stacks and one for the tabs in the stacks. I don't do that because I like the accordion view better. Seriously, Vivaldi has some really cool ways of dealing with tabs. I don't think I'm capable of switching to a different browser, even if I wanted to. I even use it for email and RSS feeds.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:48

@adamsdesk I use the Workspaces feature extensively, so each workspace has 10-20 tabs open. They're broken down by subject usually. We're on the market for a house, so I have a workspace with all my house stuff. I actually have a rule that just moves all tabs from certain websites to that workspace automatically to help me be organized. I have a workspace for college. I have one dedicated to Fosstodon, and one for email. One is for news, and there's one that just for random stuff.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:44

@graves501 I do use vim, but that search functionality is already built into Vivaldi. I can search in several different ways actually. I can go to the Window panel, and type in the search bar at the top. I can start typing in the address bar and it will show me any open tabs I have with matching information, or I can hit CTRL-Space and start typing there with about the same results. I can switch to open tabs or open a new one depending on my needs. It's pretty slick.

@adamsdesk

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:42

@adamsdesk I tend to leave them open until they're not useful to me anymore. I don't use bookmarks because I suffer from an "out of sight out of mind" problem, and end up just opening pages back up without using the bookmarks. Having the tab open means the task that required that tab is still unfinished, and seeing them reminds me of things I'm still working on.

@RL_Dane

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:40

@xpil Fair point! If I can pull this off maybe I'll do 102 days just so the intro and outro don't count.

@yabozdar @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:38

@RL_Dane I'll mention it to her. That functionality is built in to Vivaldi, so I've never looked into the add-ons.

@adamsdesk

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:37

@adamsdesk Well, I can't speak for her of course. For me, I don't worry about crashes since tabs are synced to the Vivaldi cloud. I can see what I've got open on any computer, phone, or tablet running Vivaldi. If it crashes, it just comes right back up. Performance doesn't take much of a hit since Vivaldi automatically hibernates tabs after they've been open and unused. Minimal memory footprint. I have 101 tabs open in Vivaldi for about 1.5GB RAM. Firefox has over 1GB RAM for 7 right now.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:10

@adamsdesk She's like me when it comes to tabs. Probably worse since she has dozens and dozens if not hundreds of tabs open across multiple windows. I just use Workspaces in #Vivaldi to organize my tabs so it's like having more than one window without actually doing it. It also makes finding stuff like this easier. Long story short, she couldn't find the tab so she restarted. That made the sounds go away.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-16 20:08

@kev Yep, but the challenge was for by December 31st. We can all blame @yabozdar for that one. ðŸ˜‰

Mike Stone @mike 2024-08-14 17:08

@FinchHaven @dcz Good advice. Also, if you go to the profile of the individual you're wanting to follow, in the Hamburger menu, there's an option to open the original page. That will view the individual's profile through their own instance, not what your instance sees. Even if they're blocked on Fosstodon, you can see everything that's public or unlisted at the very least. I have to say though, if you can see the profile and follow it, it's probably not blocked in any way.

Josh Bressers @joshbressers 2024-07-24 13:44

OK Mastodon #OpenSource folks, this is your time to shine

I need some examples of common open source myths. This will have a security slant to it when I put it all together, but I'm not only looking for security examples, I want all types

Here are a few I've cooked up, but I know there are ton more

- Most projects have more than one maintainer

- Most projects are part of a large foundation like Eclipse or Linux Foundation

- There are many options for libraries and you can swap them out if needed

- Open source is more secure than closed source

- Open source is less secure than closed source

- Most projects have funding driving the development

- If I use open source in my product, I have to open source the whole product

- If the source code is available, itâ€™s open source

- There are a few thousand open source projects

I want them all, no matter how small, silly, or obvious you think they are, let me know

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-19 17:11

@kev Yea, unfortunately not everybody who uses their products are so objective. A few years back, I was talking to a good friend of mine who is a rabid Apple guy and he was mentioning that there was a new product coming from Apple (I don't remember which one). He literally said, "I don't know what it is, but I'm buying it." Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-19 16:45

@kev Apple's modus operandi has long been, "You'll take what we give you and like it." They've had great success in the last couple decades based on that philosophy. Even when they make a shit product, their faithful still use it and many will defend it and say it's good because it's Apple.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-19 15:21

@kingannoy Agreed.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-18 22:04

They just pretty much throw a guard on the trimmer and move it until it stops cutting. I still have to fix it after they're done. I'm in search of somewhere that does it better, but so far it's just best if I do it at home for now.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-17 18:06

@kev It's an interesting question. Sadly I'm not sure I COULD give it up if I wanted to. I love Fosstodon and I have no desire to leave it, but even OTHER platforms I would love see in the rear view I've had trouble vacating completely. To my shame, I still have an account on Meta's Face platform. I don't used now, but when my mom passed away a few years ago it was what I used to coordinate family stuff. All other social media is once a week/month, but it's still there. Just in case.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-17 17:56

@kev @sirobsidian Honestly, to me being an admin adds a layer of exhaustion to the whole thing. I love Fosstodon, there's no question about that, and I'm extremely proud of what we've done here, but being an admin does make my "social media experience" feel more like a job than recreation. It's the first thing I do in the morning and the last thing I do at night before going to sleep. Thankfully we have a great moderation team to help us out and we're allowed to take a break if we need to.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-15 17:50

@sheogorath I guess it's fairly dependent on your opinion of your own writing. I'm fairly critical of mine, so confirmation I'm not writing like a 5 year old is appreciated. If you're looking at collegiate level writing as a baseline, I can see why you'd be offended.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-15 16:28

It's always gratifying to me when I write something for a college class and the professor includes feedback that says I write at a college level. It's a generic, filler piece of feedback that I'm sure gets plopped onto most submissions by pretty much everybody, but I have a pretty low opinion of my writing so even the slightest bit of validation gives me the warm fuzzies.

Note: This is not a request for validation.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-11 06:36

@AAMfP I know there are more complex elements that are in many documents, but more often than not CommonMark is going to meet your needs. It's not fancy or anything, but if you're writing a document you're rarely going to go outside of it's capabilities. That being said, multiple formats of markdown wouldn't be impossible. There's already eight different Word options between documents and other stuff.

@libreoffice

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-10 23:07

@dusnm Sure, but they have options for Rich Text and just plain text too. When you're saving it just pops up a dialog that says, "This document may contain formatting or content that cannot be saved in the currently selected file format." Markdown could work the same way.

@libreoffice

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-10 22:44

Am I the only one that thinks it would be really nice if @libreoffice had an option to Save As markdown? I'm legitimately surprised that's not already a feature.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-07 05:23

Just a refresher for people who have been around, and maybe new information for people who have joined recently.

Fosstodon is an invite only instance, but any member of our community can invite others to join, and we encourage you to do that!

That being said, if you're inviting people to our community, please don't issue invites with no limits. Also, if we need to ban 6 people in a week and 5 of them were invited by one person, we're going to start asking questions, so use discretion.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-07 04:03

@zyxhere@mastodon.social

If you didn't already get one.

https://fosstodon.org/invite/7U4YcB2Q

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-07 04:03

@djmitche Here's an invite for you if you don't already have one.

https://fosstodon.org/invite/VMRNQzTK

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-07 03:08

@codeDude @zyxhere@mastodon.social Anybody is free to send invites.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-07 03:05

@blairconrad Ahhhh, no. Not yet anyway. It would be a cool option to have that functionality anywhere not just in the address bar. Maybe it's something we'll see in a future release of #Vivaldi. They're always adding cool new stuff.

@Vivaldi

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-06 21:30

@blairconrad As far as I'm aware, it doesn't have a toggle in the settings. You just hold down your control key (I use the left one but the right seems to work just as well for me) and then hover over the web address in the address bar. As you move across the address it underlines the parts of the URL that are going to be active if you click on the address (like a link in a page). When you have the part of the address you want, just click the address in the address bar and it takes you there.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-06 19:19

@VincentTunru Hm, I couldn't get it to work in Firefox. Is it a configurable option I need to enable?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-06 18:22

@blairconrad Wait, you tried it in Vivaldi and it didn't work?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-06 01:03

@jennasys Awesome right? Sometimes it's the simple things that make all the difference.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-06 01:02

@monkey1 The complaints I've heard are that it's not fulling FOSS and it's Chromium based. There are some who don't like that it's got so many features, but to me that's a plus.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-06 00:11

You know those stupid little features in an app that, when you explain it to someone, they just answer, "When would I ever need to have that?" Yea, there's a feature in #Vivaldi that if you hold down the control key, you can click into parts of a URL. So, with https://fosstodon.org/deck/getting-started, I can click fosstodon.org and go there without the /deck/getting-started. I can move over to the /deck and click and get https://fosstodon.org/deck without the getting started. I use this ALL THE TIME.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-07-05 06:13

@matthartley Can't wait to see what you do with it!

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-18 19:15

@amerpie I never used to think about it much, but when I found out the inner monologue thing was actually a real thing, it just raised so many questions for me.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-18 18:21

@amerpie So is the silent voice a voice you can recognize? Like do you know it's your voice vs. Morgan Freeman or Aretha Franklin?

The visualization is also interesting. If you said, think of an apple, I don't think I'd actually picture it, so it wouldn't have any specific color. I'd consider it a more abstract idea. If you said, PICTURE an apple, then I'd probably choose a color and visualize the apple in my head at that point. I wouldn't necessarily picture it just because I'm thinking of it.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-18 18:02

@amerpie And see, that's an interesting question. What do you mean by hearing the words? When I read, there's no audio component to the thought process. There's no "voice". I process the word in my head, but it's like how you'd think of how strawberries smell (at least I'd guess). There's no "audio" required. Maybe that's the same thing as your wife? Dunno, it's a weird thing trying to describe what happens in your head when there's no external allegory.

Deleted just leaves the whole conversation in place, but weirdly orphaned at the start of the thread.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-15 05:03

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-15 04:59

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-15 04:59

@Craktok Well, they absolutely had to kill that because you can get their content but they don't have any input. They want to be able to feed you content they think will keep you on the platform. Mastodon isn't here for ad revenue or metrics, so it has no need to algorithmically manipulate you.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-14 23:17

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-14 23:00

One of the features I love about Mastodon that doesn't get much attention is one that is in your face every day, and that's the chronological stream. If I refresh my browser, I can still find the post I was looking at. It's not been moved off to some seemingly random place based on some unknown algorithm, assuming you can find it at all. It's such a simple thing, but it really makes my experience with Mastodon that much better.

Renaud Chaput @renchap 2024-06-13 21:24

I have been using #Fastly nearly since their inception, and it is one of the few tech companies that never disappointed me. They are very obsessed by performance and customer service (< 5 minute response time on tickets).

They love the Fediverse and OSS, and are providing a lot of projects (including Mastodon) with a lot of resources.

Their biggest issue? There was no free plan. But this is now fixed ðŸŽ‰

No excuse to not try the service and see by yourself: https://fastly.com/pricing

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 19:17

@mike@libertynode.net I agree. Also, why are new emoji or a new way to MAKE new emoji part of a developer conference?

#CouldaBeenAnEmail

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 19:05

@jp I don't disagree, but I think part of that is that they've diverged from Apple in how they manage their app/OS relationship, but they're still trying to emulate Apple's style of hype building. Apple's keynotes have moved from Jobs on a stage with a glorified PowerPoint behind him to Craig Federighi doing parkour through the building and highly choreographed video presentations. They all also seem to have the same handwaving coach. It's distracting from their actual announcements.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 18:54

@jp I think the problem with these Apple announcements (other than the constant handwaving and overuse of words like "magical" and "breathtaking") is that Apple has tried to make all of its apps part of its OS. Updates to Mail? Cool, but why is that part of the OS? Inversely, Google has made an effort to make virtually everything an app that's available from the store. Their apps get constant updates throughout the year. It's honestly one of the biggest distinctions between the two platforms.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 18:47

Also, serious question here. What is the deal with Apple's infatuation with emoji? Seems every conference and product announces 20,000 new emoji or a new way to make custom emoji or some other emoji thing.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 18:46

Hm, so the #WWDC keynote is over now, and the coolest thing I saw was the iPad calculator?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 16:57

@asier Even with some hypothetical ultra-amazing AI chip, that's only going to be a distinction between on device and cloud based. Apple makes some amazing hardware, but they're not going to invent anything that fits in a phone that's going to compete with a datacenter. Keeping AI on device isn't leading the market, it's just putting the AI in a particular place.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 16:52

@asier OK, but does doing a good job equate to market leadership? I'd argue that it doesn't. Maybe I'm wrong there. Maybe as long as Apple can manage a mediocre product on a lot of devices that's borderline adequate people will consider that "leadership". Throw a little Apple branded spit and polish on it, and in five years people will be saying Apple invented AI.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 16:49

@JonRowe That worked, and I'm really surprised Bloomberg has allowed a hole that big to stick around. Still, in reading that it's just a "They'll do this thing that OpenAI already does" or "They'll do this thing that Google already does" or "They'll do this thing on device instead of in the cloud". I don't see anything particularly innovative that would put Apple in a market leadership position other than pushing something derivative out to lots of devices. Is that what they're doing?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 16:13

@JonRowe That's paywalled up to its eyeballs, so can't read it. How does better Siri and a version of CoPilot for xcode translate to it leading the market? Opt-in is great, but it doesn't put Apple in a leading position regarding AI. I've heard many different hypothesis for how Apple is going to lead this market, but none make sense to me. Their own LLM based on only public data? The other guys used public data plus more. Deep integration with ChatGPT? That's not Apple leading, that's OpenAI.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-10 16:01

#WWDC starts in a little less than an hour. There are many that are expecting #Apple to come out strong with #AI products. Some have even stipulated that Apple will lead the market. My question is, what would that look like? Having a terrible AI on a lot of devices isn't really leading the market. Keeping AI on device is great for privacy reasons, but that AI is never going to compete functionally with the giant datacenter model. Only public sources is good, but everybody has that. Sooooo.... ?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-07 17:00

@twatson Well, I can't speak for everybody, but I expect it's similar to the thought process behind any FOSS project. When @kev and I first got involved we just really enjoyed Mastodon and we wanted a space for ourselves. We expected we might get half a dozen people on our instance maybe. Over time more and more people with similar interests joined us, and things got a lot more complicated. Still, it's a great community and personally I enjoy being able to help out however I can.

Mike Stone boosted
blendOS @blendOS 2024-06-07 16:20

blendOS v4 has been released! #ArchLinux made #Immutable, #Declarative, and Atomic. Define your system with a single YAML file ('/system.yaml') supporting packages/kernels/DEs from the Arch #Linux repos & #AUR.

#Flatpaks, #Android apps & #Ubuntu, #Fedora, #Debian, and #CentOS Stream packages can be installed too (#containers), and integrate with your host system.

https://blendos.co/blog/2024/06/05/blendos-v4-released-arch-linux-made-immutable-declarative-and-atomic/

P.S. We just joined Mastodon!

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-06 20:19

@twatson Yep, we have a Patreon and LiberaPay, as well as standard Paypal. We are 100% community supported financially (other than Kev and myself throwing anything we can afford). Our moderation team are fully volunteer. We have two senior moderators and six standard. Kev and I used to do this ourselves, but it just got too overwhelming, so we've stepped back from that completely at this point and we only get involved if something the team isn't comfortable with making a call on comes up.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-06 08:44

@twatson Happy to answer questions.

@tekeous If you're interested, @kev just pointed me in the direction of a 3rd party UI for Mastodon (https://phanpy.social/) that does allow for adding the Local feeds from other instances. It's a pretty slick interface, so if you're interested....

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-03 22:41

@LateNightLinux I love being able to use an RSS reader for Mastodon. In addition to standard posts, you can also see replies (https://fosstodon.org/@JoeRess/with_replies.rss) and you can follow hashtags (https://fosstodon.org/tags/LateNightLinux.rss).

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-03 19:09

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-02 08:35

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-02 08:26

@popey I think I have a collection of those in my garage. Not with the fancy dust cover or anything, so I could be convinced to part with them for half price? ðŸ˜‰

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-02 05:31

@tekeous I would love that kind of feature too, but I don't expect to see it. I think the developers of Mastodon are going a different way as they've made an effort to deprioritize local feeds and they're working on the implementation of groups (not to be confused with lists). Groups would allow for discussions specific to a subject were anybody posting to a group would be shared with any other member of the group, regardless of instance or follow status. It could be good. I'm hoping it will be.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-01 20:37

@scribe No, the Global Timeline is the same as the Federated timeline, or what many people simply refer to as "The Fed". Some of the mobile clients don't give you a version of the Explore feature. I'm not familiar with IceShrimp specifically, but in Tusky half the Explore feature is available as "Trending" menu choices. Fosstodon's Explore menu is available from any web UI if you'd like to give it a quick once over.

https://fosstodon.org/explore

Keep in mind, the People menu isn't available outside.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-01 20:27

@number6 Hate to go all, "Well, acksually" on you, but.....

https://blog.duolingo.com/duolingo-launches-math-app/

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-01 20:25

@scubbo That would be a cool feature.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-01 20:25

@vancha Naw, in Tusky (which is the client I assume you're talking about), the Explore feature is kinda broken out into multiple choices. With the Web UI, Explore has Posts, Hashtags, People, and News options, but in Tusky only the Posts (Trending Posts) and Hashtags (Trending Hashtags) make it through. I do kinda like the way they display the hashtags though. So, without waffling overmuch, Explore would be the Trending menu choices in Tusky.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-06-01 19:59

I've been on Fosstodon for as long as there's been a Fosstodon, and personally I love the Local timeline. Still, sometimes I hit up the Explore for news and to see what's going on outside my personal bubble of information. How often do you use the Explore feature here on Mastodon?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-05-29 23:14

@LateNightLinux Just finished this episode. I was a little surprised there was no mention of ladder, since I'm pretty sure I heard about it on one of your shows. I run a local instance of it, and I've created a custom "search" engine in my browser so when I run into a paywall, I just add "la " before the URL in my address bar and it strips the paywall for me like magic. It's become a pretty central part of my browsing experience.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-05-29 03:35

Mike Stone @mike 2024-05-17 17:40

@joel Rate limits do exist, but they're set so high that most of the time no one will see them. I've seen them before myself, but only when I had several apps on my phone and more than one or two tabs open to Fosstodon.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-05-17 17:35

@beardedtechguy Absolutely! In fact, when I open a new tab from an existing one, I automatically stack them. That way I'm grouping tabs that are associated without having to think about it. It lets me move groups of tabs easily between workspaces and they don't take up all the space in my tab bar. It also lets me close whole groups when I'm done with a particular task rather than having to deal with each individual tab. It doesn't sound like a lot, but all that time adds up!

@Vivaldi

Mike Stone @mike 2024-05-17 15:51

@beardedtechguy Well, I'm a tab guy, so on any given day I have easily 100+ tabs open. You can imagine then that any tab management feature gets extensive use. Workspaces was like a feature built just for me. I have a workspace for work, and one for school, and one for Fosstodon (where I spend a great deal of time), etc. I've setup Workspace Rules, so I have to be less diligent when opening new tabs and they still end up in the correct Workspaces. Amazing feature. Love it.

@Vivaldi

Mike Stone @mike 2024-05-10 20:13

@kev I'm a little concerned about the notifications for severed relationships. I don't think it's a bad idea, but I really want it to be obvious why the relationship was severed. If randominstance.social decides to block Fosstodon, we may not have any idea why that happened, and if people on Fosstodon are losing relationships over the block, those people might be rightly coming to us and our team for some WTF conversation. It would be helpful if the notifications point to the actioning instance.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-05-09 16:13

Having said that, I'd much rather see something locally run like Ollama than having every inquiry going into the DB of Microsoft, Google, or Amazon. It's bad enough all the tracking they're already doing. This just adds a whole new vector for them to track for even more information on us.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-30 16:17

@popey @testman Of course, best is a subjective measure so it really depends on your goal. I lean towards #NeonAI as it's more full featured than #OVOS, but YMMV. #HomeAssistant has also made huge strides in the voice arena, and continue to work on it. You can turn an ESP32-S3-Box-3 into a marginally capable assistant if your only goal is to control your smart home. If you want to ask it questions about the weather or actors/politicians then no. Not yet.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-30 16:10

@RTheren @popey Mycroft itself is pretty much toast. There were two forks of it which are both doing well as far as I can see. #NeonAI and #OVOS. Pretty much everybody who develops for OVOS used to work for Mycroft or NeonAI at some point. I run NeonAI on my Mark II. It's stand alone and operates entirely locally. NeonAI actually still sells the Mark II if you're interested in getting one. They will set you back a pretty penny on price.

@golemwire I'm not familiar with spd-say, but espeak absolutely would. I'll assume they both would. I'm just more familiar with piper. @MobileOak

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-26 20:24

@MobileOak It's a call to the piper tts engine that converts the provided file (should be text) to audio. The shell script that code is from is called read2me on my system, so I just type read2me file.txt and it reads the file out loud.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-26 19:27

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-26 18:49

Yes, I'm actually this lazy.

#!/usr/bin/bash

INPUT_FILE=$1

if [ ! -f ${INPUT_FILE} ]
then
echo "File ${INPUT_FILE} doesn't exist. Please try again."
exit 1
fi

cat ${INPUT_FILE} |python3 -m piper --model en_GB-alan-medium --output-raw | aplay -r 22050 -f S16_LE -t raw -

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-21 19:57

@popey Another potential option (and I'd like to reinforce that I have never used any of this in this manner) would be voice changer software like Figaro. (https://github.com/MattMoony/figaro) The intent of that software isn't what you're trying to do, but I can imagine a scenario where you could funnel the audio out from a YouTube video into the audio in of the voice changing software to do an alteration of the existing voice. Obviously this wouldn't help for strong accents, but if it's just a voice?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-21 19:31

@popey I'd suspect your best option would be transcriptions or subtitles of the audio. I've never heard of anything that would just lift and shift audio. YouTube does automatic subtitles these days, and it seems adequate (for me anyway). You can use a tool like yt-dlp to download a file with the subtitles in it. It would need some serious cleanup before it's useful. Someone with experience text parsing could probably pull it off. From there you could potentially TTS it to another voice.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-19 21:24

@jimsalter All the time. I have kids.

I also get those "fractal requests" at work. Recently I got a request to change a server name in an automated file transfer. Simple enough, It was literally an increment of the old file name, so one character different in the name server2.client.com instead of server1.client.com. Then it turns out they're using a nonstandard port, which requires a firewall change, which requires a request and approval from NetSec, which takes over a week. For 1 number.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-17 05:23

@underlap I'm going to have to spend more time on this. I tried cargo build --release, and it complained that I didn't have a Cargo.toml file, so I created a basic one that looks like this:

[package]
name = "hello_world"
version = "0.0.1"

[[bin]]
name = "HelloWorld"
path = "hello_world.rs"

The build created a directory called ./target with a release directory under it, which contained the binary and several other files. It was still 13MB.

Obviously I don't know what I'm doing. At all.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-17 03:30

@amin Compiled binary I'd assume. It's my first time, but the file does appear to be binary by all measures. Literally, the code is this:

fn main() {
println!("Hello World!");
}

I typed rustc hello_world.rs and hit enter. A binary file came out, and it's huge.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-17 03:24

I installed rustc tonight and proceeded to write HelloWorld.rs. My first ever :rust: program. And it's 13MB. What the hell??

Mike Stone @mike 2024-04-16 22:27

Random Geek @randomgeek 2024-03-31 20:15

The eldest among us remember the First Web, before search engines were Good Actually. They used secret magics to make sense of the chaos that was the First Web.

Site directories.

Web rings.

Home pages linking to trusted sites.

Homework and jello shooter recipes study notes.

Now that the Search Engines have fallen it is time to bring those ancient tools back, for ourselves and the youngest among us who never knew the First Web.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-31 07:10

@PawelK It almost seems like a perfect distributed feature to add to the Fediverse. A browser like @Vivaldi could add a backend service to the browser where commentary about individual pages could be stored. When you visit a page you have the option to see what other people have said about it, and from the Fediverse could follow individuals to see their comments. If I run across someone I feel is particularly insightful, I might want to follow up on what they're reading. Or block them if not.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-31 02:22

I love the Notes feature in #Vivaldi. Seriously, I use it all the time. Sometimes I just add quick notes in a panel. Sometimes I tile a full tab with another page so it's more of a full sized document. When I change computers or even fire up @Vivaldi on my phone, my notes are there. I can do formatting and even embed images. Seriously, it's hard to overstate how useful this feature is to me.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-27 23:19

@MobileOak There hasn't really been an update on our position regarding Threads since then. Fediverse integration with Threads is still beta, and as far as I know their content is coming out but ours isn't going in. So, you can follow a Threads user but they can't follow you. You can see their content but they can't see yours. Presently, we're still in a wait and see position. We're not going to block them for the crime of existing in the Fed, but if they become problematic...

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-27 17:55

@LateNightLinux I've always thought the inner monologue was a fascinating topic. I honestly thought it was a gimmick for movies, TV, and books to give the reader/watcher an idea of what was going on. I never thought for a minute that people were actually walking around talking to themselves in their minds. When I first ran into an article a while back about inner monologues and how "some people" don't have them, it caught me by surprise. It was a, "wait, that's real?" moment for me.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-25 02:32

I find this video amazingly helpful. I don't have #ADHD, but I often have trouble concentrating. If there's anything that can draw my attention away, it does. Even listening to more traditional music can pull me into lyrics instead of what I'm trying to focus on. When I do manage to focus, my attention is like a glass plate. If it gets broken, it REALLY gets broken. It's a battle to get all those pieces back in place.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-24 23:14

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-24 20:20

Yesterday while at the grocery store, I somehow managed to put my phone down and not pick it back up. I managed to get it back this morning, but that was stressful. I don't recall ever having done that before. Maybe we've just been super lucky, but every time anybody in my family has done this, we've always gotten it back. I think the MOST surprising thing about this whole situation isn't that I put my phone down and forgot it, it was I didn't notice it was missing for almost 8 hours.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-17 22:46

@jameswynn Even a simple GUI system to configure voice prompts would be amazing. I have an ESP32-S3-BOX-3, and if I say, "OK Nabu, how's the weather", I should be able to configure HA with a simple trigger/response where "how's the weather" pulls weather data from a SwitchBot temperature sensor I have and use that value in a "The current temperature is %switchbot.value." NeonAI and OVOS can both already use custom intents (without a GUI of course). Hopefully soon for HA.

@homeassistant @PINE64

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-17 20:43

@jameswynn Me too! Unfortunately there's not a lot of details available just yet. I don't know if this is something that's going to be more appropriate as a satellite for @homeassistant to use, or if it's going to be capable of running software like #NeonAI or #OVOS. I'd like to see the latter since NeonAI is currently a more capable voice assistant that HomeAssistant (currently), but HomeAssistant is pretty new to the game so there's no guarantees that'll always be the case.

popey @popey 2024-03-13 08:25

I have a question for you, asking in good faith. ðŸ™

What (perfectly valid) reasons are there *not* to run #linux on the primary laptop/desktop in 2024?

Excluding all of these, which are also valid:

* Specific games don't run
* Windows applications required
* Missing hardware driver
* It's someone else's computer
* Steep learning curve
* Don't like it
* Never heard of it
* Lack of technical support nearby
* Bad previous experience
* Prefer Apple hardware

Interested in other reasons.
