@talktech @Vivaldi

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 16:25

@woody We absolutely apply our data retention policy uniformly. We make no claims we'll retain deleted data, whether that data is deleted by the individual or the moderation team. Deleted is deleted. It's gone. It's not technically feasible to provide it because it's gone.

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 16:12

@woody Article 20.2, "where technically feasible". It's not feasible to provide deleted data, nor is it feasible to expect us to retain deleted data indefinitely.

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 16:07

@woody Article 12 also has no requirement data be retained indefinitely, or for any period of time at all.

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 16:05

@woody Does it?

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 16:04

@woody There's an appeal process that I believe gives you 30 days (I haven't looked for a while and it's a Mastodon default). If you don't appeal within the 30 days your data is removed permanently. Appeals are handled through a different means and logged to the original Report. If an appeal is accepted (which happens), the content is restored.

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 15:58

@woody Article 20 contains no time requirement, let alone a demand that data be retained indefinitely. I'd suggest a reread if you think it does.

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 15:56

@nafnlaus That's correct. Being reported is not a violation, nor is there any claim that it is. It's just a report. 3 times the moderator who handled the report felt it was actionable.

@woody @fosstodon @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 15:48

@woody Let's start with something a little simpler. What is the minimum required period for data retention under the GPDR? I assume you don't think I'm required to retain all data for all users indefinitely, so how long do I need to retain it?

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 15:44

@woody It does obviously allow me to look up what the reported content, who reported it (if it's on our instance, but otherwise we only get an instance name), who handled the report, and what the action was. That's why I could say that @nafnlaus was reported 16 times by 11 different instances and each of the 3 times his content was moderated the action was taken by a different individual. There were 4 posts removed, and I can't produce them because I don't have them.

@fosstodon @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 15:38

@woody Despite that, it seems to be your contention that I should be keeping a separate copy of moderated content, but let me clarify just to be sure I'm not misunderstanding you. Is it your contention that if a hypothetical user on my instance posted CSAM (purely hypothetical), it's not only my obligation to retain a copy of that material but I also must be able to return it to the individual in question or I'm in violation of the GDPR?

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 15:34

@woody Good morning.

From my point of view, you seem to have a very superficial understanding of the subject matter and because of that your expectations don't conform with reality.

I know what a ticketing system is. I've been using them for ~30 years. Ranging from using VT220s to access helpdesk software on a VAX/VMS system, Remedy, Jira, ServiceNow, etc. I've lost track of them all. There's also a rudimentary ticketing system built into Mastodon, which we use.

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 02:18

@woody I refer to the team as "we" when it's appropriate. I don't when it's not. For example, I didn't moderate any content from @nafnlaus, but WE did. When someone is asking ME, the information available to me is all I have. WE don't have a collective memory, and when we say something has been deleted, it has been. We don't have a secret backend database where deleted stuff lives forever.

@fosstodon @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 02:15

@woody Further, we as as moderation team will not just say that you think @nafnlaus is a pain in the ass, or that we disagree with him, or that speech is free as in speech but not free as in beer, or whatever.

Our team was not involved in the conversation. We received a report of content that violated our CoC, we looked at said content, and we made a decision based on that and our CoC. Sometimes that content is actioned, sometimes it is not.

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 02:11

@woody We, as a moderation team, don't "delete things because we feel like it."

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 02:09

@woody 500 characters is the Mastodon default. Most Mastodon instances have it. Changing it requires a change outside of the configuration utilities and it has to be done each time the software is updated. This is not optimal so we've stayed with the default.

@fosstodon @kev @nafnlaus

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 01:54

@woody Why make two posts? Because I ran out of space in the first one. We have a 500 character limit. Maybe I should have not broken a sentence in two if that would have been more understandable.

I feel I need to reiterate that I have never personally moderated any of the content posted by @nafnlaus, so the remainder of your post seems more than a little inappropriate.

@fosstodon @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 01:37

@woody I'm not sure how you can disagree with "moderator doing the moderation". I can only assume you didn't notice that was a sentence that was being continued from a previous post. I was simply pointing out that the person doing the moderation was different in each case. What about that do you disagree with?

@nafnlaus @fosstodon @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 01:00

@nafnlaus I'll see what I can find. Just be aware that if a report resulted in a post being removed (not saying that's something that's happened) we don't retain that post in any way. I can't provide those posts to you simply because I don't have them.

@fosstodon @dominikasafko @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 00:56

@nafnlaus moderator doing the moderation. This has happened starting in November of 2022 and most lately last month. Since you only joined Fosstodon in November of 2022, that means you've been getting reported consistently since you've joined. On average at least once a month. Maybe consider what each of those reports has in common. 2/2

@fosstodon @dominikasafko @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 00:53

@nafnlaus These are the reasons that you were reported, not necessarily the reasons you had your account limited. To answer the accusation in your last paragraph, obviously not. Not every report is actionable. That should be obvious since you've been reported 16 times and only had your account limited 3 times. Consider this: The 16 times you've been reported, the reports have come from 11 different instances and each time you've been limited was a different 1/

@fosstodon @dominikasafko @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-04 00:36

@nafnlaus The first time you were reported was November 2022, and the report was regarding Ukraine. No action was taken at the time because supporting Ukraine is not an offense according to our CoC. Neither is supporting Tesla. Some of the reasons for the reports (not all have been actioned) include:

Unsolicited spam
Trolling
Anti-Trans posts
Accusations of Racism
Aggression

I could go back and see what finally tipped the scales, but there were many options.

@fosstodon @dominikasafko @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-03 23:07

@nafnlaus Your account has been reported 16 different times for various reasons. You've been limited 3 times by 3 different moderators. The last time you had your account limited, your appeal was an accusation that we blocking you (your account has never been blocked, only limited) for supporting Tesla. If you believed it was because we were "tankies" who limited you for supporting Ukraine, that's an odd accusation.

@fosstodon @dominikasafko @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-03 22:17

@Brendanjones instance to know about another without some form of follow. Without knowledge of the instance, there's no way to exchange hashtags with those instances.

Of course, this ignores relays. We do have one relay configured, but I think @kev set that up. I don't remember honestly. It was probably added some years ago as the one we use is for only English and Italian posts. I haven't actively looked into relays since we're a big enough instance that they haven't been required. 2/2

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-03 22:13

@Brendanjones I don't really have a good answer. Instances don't choose where their hashtags go, they're sent to all instances that their instance knows about, same as the Fed. The instance learns about another instance via follows. Each instance delivers messages directly to other instances, and doesn't go through another instance for propagation. I don't think (and I'm sure someone will correct me if I'm wrong) instances exchange their known instances lists. So there's no way for one 1/

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-02 23:38

@ckae They spelled "Fosstodon" wrong in the link. They put "Fosstofon".

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-01 21:41

@gloopsies Well, it is based on Chromium, but in my opinion it far surpasses it for pretty much every metric. Integrated mail, calendar, markdown based notes, translation tool, window tiling, workspaces. The UI is configurable like no other browser, and it has options on top of options, like you can sync your Phillips Hue bulbs with the color scheme of the web page you're looking at. Vivaldi is just so much more than Chrome. Still, I get the open source thing. It's on my wish list.

@Vivaldi

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-01 17:50

@janet Congratulations! I've thought about doing the same thing!

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-01 17:49

@talktech It's my go-to for pretty much everything. The list of things "I wish it did" has been worn down to almost nothing. It seems like every time I think to myself, "Wouldn't it be cool if.." that's in the next release. It can be as simple or as complex as you want it to be. My UI is pretty basic, but that's misleading. I've got custom buttons with Command Chains that do a variety of virtually automated tasks for me. In my opinion, it's the best browser available right now.

@Vivaldi

Mike Stone @mike 2024-03-01 17:40

Leap Day this year came with a new and shiny #Vivaldi release, including the ability to have extensions work in panels! I'm still waiting for @Vivaldi to give me the pretty version of RSS feeds in a panel, but I'm willing to wait.

https://vivaldi.com/new/

popey @popey 2024-02-28 14:43

Q: What's the most underrated software tool or application that's been a game-changer for you?

I think it might have been TextPad++ for me. A text editor I used on Windows from the mid-1990s until I switched to #linux .

It had so many advanced features over the default editors at the time. I heavily leaned on the macro ðŸ“¹ record and playback function to manipulate data files.

It also had a super column-select tool before any other editor I'd known. It really helped with data processing.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-28 15:46

@popey I'd probably go with GNU Screen. It fades into the background and is almost never noticed by anybody, but it saves me so much time I can't even begin to quantify. If I'm on a computer, I've probably got it running, and that's been true for over 20 years now.

Any issues or questions, please let me know.

Thanks ðŸ˜

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-23 17:18

Fosstodon has been upgraded to version 4.2.8 of the Mastodon software. This is a nice release as it comes with a couple new features to help reduce spam in the Fed. They won't change how Fosstodon works, but their inclusion will mean we'll be seeing less unwelcome influx from outside of our instance, and that's a very good thing. Don't hesitate to read the release notes if you're interested. They're short.

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v4.2.8

Also, if you have any questions, you know where to find us.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-22 19:45

@admin Anybody looking for a new home can drop me a DM for an invite to Fosstodon if they're interested.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-21 15:25

@atoponce It's understandably annoying, and we appreciate your reporting the messages that are getting to you. I also appreciate Erik's efforts. Unfortunately, the instances we're getting messages from this morning are largely not in Erik's list and none of the messages that are being sent are coming from Fosstodon. All the email filtering stuff is for instances that are having accounts registered on their instance, which isn't us. We're doing our best to keep the tide at bay.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 19:39

@Mehrad Absolutely there's a need of some way to recognize spam and deal with it. This spam wave was stupid. It wasn't subtle and how it was spreading was obvious, and we still barely had the tools required to keep it in check. It required hours of work from moderation teams. A ridiculous amount actually.

@wholesomedonut @thelinuxcast @BrodieOnLinux @jerry

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 18:57

@Mehrad Well, the data is pretty straight forward actually. All the accounts originated on instances with open registrations. The account names were randomized and exactly 10 characters each. There was no profile picture (/avatars/original/missing.png) and no header (/headers/original/missing.png). They followed nobody and had no followers (usually). They usually posted one of two images. Examples can be found with profile lm9ztxuz4q at instance don.neet.co.jp.

@jerry @wholesomedonut

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 17:47

@amin @jdp23 Without knowing any details about this, if it were me I'd guess you'd want to use the local=true otherwise the list could potentially be massive. I'd guess they'd also limit the number of responses. This would let them offload account name lists to the remote instances. Mastodon does have an option for blocking API access, but I think it's pretty much an all or nothing scenario, so doing it would block all sorts of things you really want to have working.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 17:35

@Mehrad Sure. What do you have in mind?

@jerry @fosstodon @wholesomedonut

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 17:32

@jdp23 @amin Maybe? I can't say for certain because I don't know the code the script kiddies were using, but maybe it had to do with API structure? I don't know how they were scraping account names, but maybe it's harder in GtS? Or maybe it's just different enough that they wrote a Mastodon version and were too lazy to bother adapting for other platforms? I don't know. All speculation.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 17:03

@amin I got nothing. Maybe they were going off a static instance list? That would be weird as it would limit its reach, but stranger things right?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 16:46

@dev_ric Ahh, you're right. I did a quick search and came back with https://github.com/ncruces/zenity but didn't read it close enough. My bad.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 16:38

@amin I don't know why that would be either. I didn't think they were putting that much thought into who they were targeting to even know it was GoToSocial or not. I mean, I got a LOT of spam myself, and if they were trying to hit the most people possible, targeting an admin directly doesn't seem like a way to go unnoticed longer.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 16:31

@amin That really is surprising. We didn't have any accounts posting the spam that originated here, but there were enough abandoned instances out there that left open their registrations that there was a lot of fallout. One thing I hope it succeeded in if nothing else is showing how inadequate the moderation tools are to deal with a situation like that. Hopefully the Mastodon team will take it seriously.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 16:27

@kev Roughed this bash up in a minute or two. Just a dialog box asking if you're sure. You'd just replace the "echo SOCIALMEDIA" for a command line call to Mona. Should work. Maybe. No MacOS experience, so not totally sure on paths.

#!/bin/bash

msvar=$(zenity --info --title 'Sanity Check' \
--text 'Are you REALLY sure you want to spend time on SOCIAL MEDIA right now?' \
--ok-label Yes \
--extra-button No \
)

if [ "${msvar}" != "No" ]
then
echo SOCIALMEDIA
fi

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-20 16:13

@kev I try to avoid MacOS (and Apple products in general), but I would think given it's Unixy nature it should be pretty trivial to put a #Python based wrapper around the app. Just use a shortcut to call the Python app, have it do whatever you want (math or trivia or just a "Are you SURE?" kinda dialog), and then launch the app if it receives the correct input.

We appreciate everybody's patience over the last couple days regarding the spam wave the Fediverse has been experiencing. Positively, none of the spam has originated from Fosstodon. Negatively, that means we have very little ability to block it beyond suspending the accounts when they appear and notifying remote admins. Many instances have been very proactive, and we thank them for that. Also, thank you for all the reports you've been sending. They let both us and remote admins act more quickly.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-10 01:38

I'm personally offended by my IT class having a section titled "Command Line Network Utilities" with a thumbnail showing a hard drive with the cover removed exposing the platters and "chkdsk" above it followed by green text saying "Error Fixed".

Two things.

1. chkdsk isn't a network utility.
2. You can run chkdsk until the stars burn out, but it's never going to fix a hard drive with the platters open to the world. Just isn't going to happen.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 21:15

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 19:21

@fedops @tcely I saw that one in my class too, but it was only really mentioned one time along with some others like Body Area Networks (BANs). PANs stuck with me because it's shown up multiple times. I don't think I've ever heard any of them outside of a class.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 19:11

@fedops @tcely So strange. I remember working with a lot of Bluetooth stuff in that time frame, but I don't remember it ever being referred to as a PAN. Honestly, LAN and WAN are the only variants of that I've heard with any regularity. And VLAN I guess, but still...

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 19:02

Does anybody actually use the term "Personal Area Network" and abbreviate it PAN? I've seen that a couple times lately in my college class, and in almost 30 years in this field I don't think I've ever heard it in practice.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 18:37

I think one of my "favorite" types of phishing emails lately is the one from the Postal Service asking me to correct my address on a package delivery.

So, let me get this straight. The Postal Service, that doesn't have my email address, found my email address and somehow know it's actually me, and messaged me to correct my shipping address, which they know because they're the postal service.

Yea, that makes TOTAL sense.

:masto_face_with_rolling_eyes:

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 17:52

@anonimno Yea, I'm the same way. Unfortunately what I want and what needs to happen for me to keep my job are in conflict sometimes. If I had my way, I'd probably just put it in DND with some tailored allowances for family and a smattering of friends. There's no apps I have on my phone that are "personal" that I need timely, audio based notifications for. All that's work stuff.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 17:45

@anonimno I'm getting to be more and more of a leave me alone type lately. I really used to like getting notifications regarding a variety of things, but they just piled on and kept coming and kept coming. I appreciate random notifications a lot less now. I just want specific notifications to get though at specific times on specific dates. This should be something that's configurable in the application settings IMHO instead of having to dig around in 30 different menus (30 is hyperbole).

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 17:36

@tcely I've done that in the past too, but I had problems with it. If a number isn't in the contact then it doesn't let them through, and that means I'm missing high priority calls regarding production issues from work. In short, that's not good. Just getting the right mix of what gets through and what doesn't at what times on what days is such a tangled mess.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 17:19

@tcely Yea, I'm actually using the Focus settings in the Digital Wellbeing & Parental Controls. DND has sometimes taking things with it that weren't intended which has been a problem. One example is we get automated phone calls when a production issue occurs. Those phone calls come from a phone bank, so not always from the same number. I've had DND block those calls before because the number was unrecognized. Again, it's not that this can't be done. It's that it requires so much fiddling.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 16:57

@juliank Yea, I have a FitBit Sense, and it's good for only allowing certain notifications through, but one it doesn't allow you to schedule it. Example: I want Teams notifications to get through during my work day, but not while I'm sleeping.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 16:55

@tcely I imagine. I more care about getting them and getting them in a timely manner than the actual contents. Teams is a big one where I need to be notified that people are trying to reach me during the day, but after a specific time I don't want to get those notifications. We've been having a production issue the last couple days, and so I've needed to know ASAP when someone is messaging me even if I've stepped away from my computer for a minute. But not at 1:30 in the morning.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-09 16:36

Notifications on phones are a double edged sword. There are times I want notifications and times I outright NEED notifications. During those times I only want some things getting through. It seems like the tools required are there to make the experience livable, but tuning it to work the way I want is not an easy task. I use an Android phone, and there's the "Digital Wellbeing" section allows control of notifications during specific times, but I feel this should be part of the app configuration.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-06 16:43

@vkc In my opinion, it's less about the information than how the information is presented. If I clicked on your example video/article and had to wade through 95% advertising to get to a miniscule amount of valid information, I still would consider that clickbait. The intent is to draw my eye to get me to look at their ads, the information is the bait, true or not.

Dan Gillmor @dangillmor 2024-02-05 18:50

Take a few minutes to read this important blog post from @pluralistic. He got scammed, and he describes what happened. https://pluralistic.net/2024/02/05/cyber-dunning-kruger/#swiss-cheese-security

We're heading into a time when the scammers are gaining the upper hand, no matter how good we are at trying to avoid being taken by experts.

That's the thing: They are experts.

Get ready to do business less conveniently in the near future.

@kev Ooo, what'd ya get?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-01 22:25

@zachfeldman General PC hardware stuff, working mostly with Windows 10 and Windows 11, though they do have some sections on macOS and Linux. Linux sections are pretty superficial and so far have been exclusively Ubuntu. There's RAID configurations and hardware installations in a simulated environment. CPUs, RAM, video cards and power supplies. The section I'm on right now is focusing on device driver troubleshooting.

@smeg

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-01 21:01

@smeg That's one of the craziest bits about it. I don't really care about the certification. The class is a requirement for my major, so I have to take it. I spent a number of years working desktop support to put myself through college the first time I went, and did a year at a call center when I first moved to Phoenix to pay the bills. The work I do now isn't desktop related, so none of this stuff ever comes up. I don't expect it'll ever come up later. It's just checking a box.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-01 20:56

One of my classes this semester is A+ Exam Prep for Computer Hardware Configuration and Support. I can only describe my feelings about this class as visceral. My mind instinctively recoils from doing so much of this. The most prevalent thought in my head the entire time I'm working on it is, "How can I get out of this?" Only 4 more weeks and I'm done with this one.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-02-01 20:03

@darth

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 19:39

@darth I'd disagree. While it is their operating system, it's my computer. As such, my preferences should take precedent over theirs. That's especially true of a corporation that's still well within range of a monopolistic share of the market. Using a monopoly in one market to keep competition at bay in another market is not OK in my opinion.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 19:19

I'm forced to use Windows 11 for my work computer, and I can't honestly say without looking what my default browser is. I have #Firefox, #Vivaldi, and of course Edge because it's pushed by corporate. I solve most of my problems by just not closing my browser. Ever. Occasionally Windows "helpfully" puts Edge into my taskbar for me and I helpfully delete it as soon as I see it. Still, this is beyond the pale. If Microsoft won't stop doing it, the courts should stop them.

https://www.osnews.com/story/138410/platform-tilt-documenting-the-uneven-playing-field-for-an-independent-browser-like-firefox/

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 18:19

@autiomaa I don't have many problems with Bluesky actually. I'm not a fan of Jack Dorsey being directly involved, but as long as everything remains fully open source and distributed, it shouldn't matter. I more find myself annoyed that they reinvented the wheel with their incompatible AT protocol rather than helping with the existing ActivityPub protocol, making everything in the existing Fed completely incompatible. If they enabled ActivityPub compatibility, I'd be OK federating with them.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 17:23

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 16:38

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 16:26

I don't have a good keyboard. Don't get me wrong, it's working fine. I bought it in July of 2019 for $24 American and it's still perfectly functional. Lately it's become more and more noticeable to me that the little tabs on the F and J keys that help touch typists find home row have worn completely down to nothing. I'm tossing around the idea of just replacing the keycaps since the keyboard still works fine. Or a new one?

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 16:19

@johnefrancis I agree, and it does seem like it's getting faster pickup. I'd love to see other Fediverse options getting similar uptake. I'd love to see ActivityPub built into all manner of places. Interoperability is really the killer feature. There's been so many years of everybody wanting to silo everything. Maybe I'm wrong, but I feel like people are sick of it.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 15:59

@autiomaa Agreed. Honestly, there's no rule against having a Mastodon account AND having an account on those other services. If they're using those services and don't have a Mastodon account, I'd highly recommend getting one. It's minimal effort to setup the account, and that will allow for the comparison in interactions. It's my experience interactions here are better than in those other places.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-22 15:51

Something I've come to realize lately is, at least in technology circles, it's not uncommon for authors of articles I read and developers of applications I use to have Mastodon accounts. I realize Mastodon still hasn't broken into Meta or X numbers, but it's gratifying to see even this level of success.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-16 20:19

@dHeinemann Hey, I wanted to follow up with you on the report you filed. It's most likely due to this:

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/18708#issuecomment-1163858931

In looking into it, it's probable that the person you reported wasn't the origin of the post, but was replying to a post from [at] tk [at] f.kawa-kun.com wondering pretty much the same thing you were. [at] tk [at] f.kawa-kun.com is a Friendica instance, and as such handles mentions differently than Mastodon. I checked the original profile and the post in question 1/

I don't disagree, but man that command prefix (Ctrl-B) is just hard to get used to. I know I can change it in the config, but I'm trying not to so I'm used to how it's default installed. It just doesn't feel intuitive. It's so much more of a stretch to get to.

royal @royal 2024-01-04 21:30

I wonder how Linux distributions will remap the Microsoft Copilot key that's appearing on some new Win11 laptops.

#linuxDesktop #copilot #microsoft #keyboards

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-04 21:02

@homeassistant

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-04 17:55

@tulpa No clue, but I know I didn't get a vote.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-04 17:54

@amoroso Well, "good idea" is relative. It's another way to milk people of more information which gets them more money, so it's a good idea in their estimation. Good idea for you and I? No, they don't care about that at all.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-04 17:52

@daaain Well, since Copilot doesn't really exist in any official way on platforms other than Windows, Windows becomes the focal point. Whether Microsoft is going to allow for a key remapping is up for debate. You can bet on it being buried under 10 miles of menus if it's an option at all. Further, this places Microsoft's specific logo on the keyboards of people that may not even be using the product. That's advertising and mind share. Putting it there makes Copilot the de facto standard.

Mike Stone @mike 2024-01-04 17:33

See, here's the thing. I don't mind AI. I kind of like it actually. I want it to be local, not cloud, so privacy is maintained, but that's besides the point I'm trying to make. I don't need some AI assistant key on my keyboard. I didn't need or want a Windows key, I don't need or want a "Copilot" key. This is a bad idea.

https://www.osnews.com/story/138199/microsoft-and-windows-oems-to-put-dedicated-ai-copilot-key-on-keyboards/

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-30 22:54

@jotaemei Virtually all day to day decisions are made by our moderation team.

https://hub.fosstodon.org/team/

We have a MatterMost instance where they have private channels to discuss.

If a decision is more than day to day business, we'll often go to our sponsors first and then the general community and let them decide. @kev and I are the founders of the instance, and as such we have veto rights over any decisions, but we have never done that and never plan to.

@chadmccullough@mozilla.social @zabbeer @munk

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-30 07:42

@chadmccullough@mozilla.social In fairness, that's Kev's personal blog. We've looked into the negatives and the positives regarding federation with Threads, and at this point we feel the positives for our community outweigh the negatives. This is subject to change as more data becomes available. We're continuing to monitor the situation, and if it changes we'll update our response.

@zabbeer @munk

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-30 01:32

@chadmccullough@mozilla.social The @LateNightLinux podcasts are most of the podcasts I listen to. Pretty much anything @JoeRess makes. The only other ones I listen to with any regularity is #HowToFixTheInternet from the #EFF and #MysteryAIHypeTheater3000 from @alex and @emilymbender. I like Joe's because they're quick and accessible, plus I value the opinions of the people involved. How To Fix The Internet and Mystery AI Hype Theater 3000 are a little bit more involved so those require some time to settle in.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-23 08:26

@thx1766 It's possible that your other instance may be running something custom. I don't know for sure without looking into it, but we try to keep Fosstodon as close to vanilla as we possibly can. If things look different that may be the reason why.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-23 06:51

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-23 00:15

@shom I don't mind discussing it. It's good to understand other people's perspectives. I agree there's value in the authorized fetch, but I have to try to balance that value against the negatives that come with it. The biggest question I have right now is whether the value our community gets is more than the cost of basically blocking all Lemmy and kbin instances for the foreseeable future. I expect eventually Lemmy and kbin will work with it. Do we block them until then, or wait?

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-22 21:04

@shom Check out the section of that post under "Disallow Unauthenticated API Access".

"thereâ€™s a second protocol, the Mastodon API that clients and apps use to communicate with Mastodonâ€™s server backend."

"Again, by default, anonymous access is allowed to public posts and profile information. Somebody who is determined to circumvent a server suspension can still access public information anonymously through the Mastodon API."

AUTHORIZED_FETCH and the api are different things.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-22 17:28

@shom timelines, but doing so would still allow access to individual profiles. Only the timelines wouldn't be visible from outside. I guess the short (too late for that!) answer is turning on AUTHORIZED_FETCH doesn't keep instances from retrieving information unless you go hog wild and turn on other features and disable even more. Doing so impacts more than just instances that are blocked. Also, AUTHORIZED_FETCH breaks Lemmy and kbin access, whether they're blocked or not. 2/2

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-22 17:21

@shom No, you're not wrong here. When we block an instance that instance can still retrieve posts from Fosstodon. But enabling AUTHORIZED_FETCH doesn't change anything about the Mastodon API, and anonymous access to that is still allowed. Further, our timelines are currently public, so anybody can view them from the web just by going to our site. We could block API access, but that would break the page for people who aren't logged in. We could turn off access to the public 1/

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-22 04:28

@shom We're not opposed to implementing it. It just seemed the negatives outweighed the positives. If someone shows us that's not the case, we'd turn it on for sure.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-21 23:44

@duhdugg Or maybe it's just because I'm super tired. Jury is still out. I'm about spent for the week, so apologies if I've missed the obvious.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-21 23:39

@duhdugg That's funny, but I have some bad news. Defederating from other instances wouldn't stop anybody from scraping public data. It's public, and anybody can see it, federated or not. You can see it for yourself. Open up a new private window in the browser of your choice. Open https://fosstodon.org/@duhdugg. All your posts and your profile information is there to be seen, no authentication required. Heck, you've got an RSS feed. Anybody with a feed reader can follow you.

https://fosstodon.org/@duhdugg.rss

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-21 03:09

@Onlineadviser Of course, I'd love to see more development. Maybe a game UI for turn based games that used DMs as the back end? Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-21 03:00

@Onlineadviser I'm not super worried about it at this juncture. There's been some really interesting development and integration in the last year. I know what people think of Threads, but the fact ActivityPub is even on their radar is notable. Flipboard just started their integration with the Fediverse, and Wordpress has also started integrating. There's been some really interesting development with Lemmy and PeerTube. Having been here the better part of a decade, things are looking exciting!

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-20 20:59

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-20 18:42

@BigAngBlack I'm a little light on specifics myself, but I imagine it would work something like a torrent file, where your posts would be collected into a datastore that others could subscribe to. You'd subscribe to the datastore of others, and your device would parse their datastore and dump it out as individual posts. It could work similarly to streaming video, but with much lower bandwidth requirements. In my head at least. I don't know enough about it to be sure it could actually work.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-20 16:53

@BigAngBlack Hmmm, almost more of a P2P social network, which has real potential. The pinnacle of decentralized.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-20 05:42

@BigAngBlack Probably less, but there are always going to be people that want someone else to host for them. Being able to just pop off to some other environment at the drop of a hat would be an amazing option. Like migrating from Mastodon to PixelFed or something similar.

@forgejo

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-20 04:13

@BigAngBlack The sad thing is it wouldn't take much. Just one of these services building their software as modular with a central "account" component that could be accessed through a UI module. As long as the UI is kept separate from the account, the account could be reused for other UIs (services), and it would also ease account migrations from one instance to another.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-19 23:09

@Tertle950 Dunno. I can see how it could be pretty easily used for any turn based game. Anything more real time might be complicated.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-19 23:04

@BigAngBlack Reiterating that I love Mastodon, I still think that perhaps we're making Fediverse accounts too specific to a particular service. I haven't thought about this extensively, so maybe this is a stupid idea, but having a more generic Fediverse account where the same instance/account could be looked at with different UIs to accomplish different goals.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-19 22:26

What are some other ways we could use ActivityPub and the Fediverse other than how we currently are? Not just a clone of an existing service, but something new!

@Corvus @adamsdesk

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-12 17:32

@rl_dane We were mostly Windows servers at the time. We had one Unix guy that had his own private office in the back that never spoke to the rest of us. I didn't work for the CS department though, just the general University. The CS department was all Digital Unix, but mainly it was administrated by the CS profs.

@bonoky @adamsdesk

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-12 16:08

@bonoky Yep, 94-99. I just used to love being able to get my hands on hardware and software that I'd never be able to come close to on my own. I remember getting a DEC Alpha system in and just gaming on that thing for hours. It wasn't even actually that good because those systems just weren't intended for games, but it was still better than the cobbled together Frankenstein machine that I had. Constantly getting the new hotness was my favorite thing.

@rl_dane @adamsdesk

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-12 15:41

@bonoky I went for computer science the first time. It was back in the mid 90s, and CS was the only "computer" major that was offered at my little rural University. Didn't have a lot of income at the time, so I paid my way through by doing support. I went from desktop support of Win95/98 to Windows servers and eventually was a SysAdmin. My first full time job was coding in this hacked together proprietary language that I figured out fast I hated. Back to SysAdmin....

@rl_dane @adamsdesk

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-12 15:34

School before college was not super challenging, and my biggest problem the first time I did college was actually figuring out how to study. Before that you just showed up for class and you picked up enough from ambient noise to blow through anything they wanted you to learn. College was a little bit more complex.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-12 03:07

@adamsdesk Just started. The classes are all 100 level stuff. There's a class on how to be a college student. That one was weird. Another one is basically how to use Microsoft Office. That one was basic but there was still some nibblings of stuff that is useful. The other one is Computer Ethics, which is the one I have left. Lots of AI discussion in that one, but only on a theoretical level. It's basically a philosophy class with a bit of "cyber" sprinkled on top.

@parkr I think they'd be more useful here to use as a buffer rather than a backup. During the summer months when it's extremely hot my power bill can be as extreme as the heat. Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-08 22:30

@RyanHyde I haven't looked that closely, so take this with a grain of salt, but the Lightnings aren't actually that bad comparatively. Shooting for some modicum of equivalence, the cheapest 4 door F150 gas truck on Ford's website (area specific I'm sure) is a Lariat which starts at $57480. All models of Lightning come with 4 doors, and the cheapest version of the Lightning is $49995. It's not cheap, but cars aren't cheap these days if you buy new. I don't know there's a massive difference.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-08 20:18

@ross Yea, I've seen them for solar installations, but I can't honestly say that I've seen it used as a buffer/backup for the grid. Seems like a great option. Having your battery have wheels I'm still a little on the fence about, but if you're going to buy a car and don't want to front the expense for a household UPS, I guess it's good.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-08 20:17

@dev_ric Yea, not a big fan to be honest.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-08 20:16

@RyanHyde Yea, I've seen them in relation to solar power, but not just as a backup/buffer for the grid.

There's a solid point in the fact that pretty much everybody needs a car (at least in the United States). My only concern is that vehicles are meant to go places, and not be attached to your home at all times. That means you're running the risk of 1. running out of power for your vehicle because of your use with the house, and 2. not having the vehicle available when it's needed.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-12-08 20:13

@dx It was borderline. I've seen the home batteries before, but really only in relation to solar installations. I can't say that I can recall ever seeing them as a buffer for the grid. I might just not be paying attention to the right sources of information.

Mike Stone boosted
someodd @someodd 2023-11-26 22:29

For #Fosstodon, where's a good place to paste code snippets?

Mike Stone @mike 2023-11-27 03:29

@app4soft Fosstodon currently uses LibreTranslate. Other instances such as .social use DeepL. Neither will auto detect when used through Mastodon.

@moshidon @megalodon @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2023-11-26 18:54

@app4soft Yes, LibreTranslate does, but that functionally isn't currently available in Mastodon.

@moshidon @megalodon @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2023-11-26 16:23

@indie1337_1@vivaldi.net Sorry to hear that. That's a long time to be a dick. I hope he can get his issue figured out sooner rather than later.

Mike Stone @mike 2023-11-26 16:21

@app4soft If it doesn't already appear, that means as far as Mastodon knows, the post is already in your preferred language. If the translate option was provided on all posts, some mechanism would also be required to specify what language is being translated from. Just having a translate button won't get the job done.

@moshidon @megalodon @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2023-11-25 17:02

@app4soft Translation for Mastodon still needs some work. There's no smart language detection or anything like it. When you post, you specify what language you're posting in. If you don't change it, Mastodon uses the default from your settings. If your preferred language from the settings matches the language specified on the post, there's no Translate option. The actual contents of the post are never taken into consideration.

@moshidon @megalodon @fosstodon

Mike Stone boosted
CatSaladðŸˆðŸ¥— (D.Burch) :blobcatrainbow: @catsalad 2023-11-17 13:36

Google announced that starting in June 2024, ad blockers such as uBlock Origin #uBO will be disabled in Chrome 127 and later with the rollout of Manifest V3 (#Mv3).

The new #Chrome manifest will prevent using custom filters and stops on demand updates of blocklist. Only #Google authorized updates to browser extension will be allowed in the future, which mean an automatic win for Google in their battle to stop YouTube #AdBlockers .

#ManifestV3 is deceitful and threatening to your privacy, and now is a good time to switch to #Firefox (@mozilla) and/or #TorBrowser (@torproject) if you haven't done so already!

EFF (@eff) on Googleâ€™s Manifest V3:

âš ï¸â https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2021/12/chrome-users-beware-manifest-v3-deceitful-and-threatening
âš ï¸â https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2021/12/googles-manifest-v3-still-hurts-privacy-security-innovation

Chrome Manifest V3 Transition Timeline (2023-11-16)

ðŸš©â https://developer.chrome.com/blog/resuming-the-transition-to-mv3/

EDIT for clarification: MV3 in Chrome will still allow some ad blocking extensions, but will severely limit their blocking ability and even restricts pre-set filters to 50 MAX.

Person1: Hey Mike, Thing1 is broken.
Me: OK, let me look at.
Me: I can't see why Thing1 is broken because of Reason1. You'll have to contact Person2 and maybe they can help you out.
Person1: OK, I'll contact Person2. Thanks!
...
5 minutes later
...
Person2: Hey Mike, Thing1 is broken. Can you take a look at it?

And it keeps telling me that.

Every.
Single.
Day.

Paying that $0.70 requires a $3.00 processing fee?

Mike Stone @mike 2023-10-14 00:22

Also, there seems to be something about when it's on a plane that it struggles with. I don't know if I have a service running in the background or something that's burning through battery faster when it can't reach the Internet or not, but the battery is draining significantly faster when I'm in the air than on the ground. Research on that required.
